abstracts.cdata!:
The second phase of the School-Based
            Management Project for the United Mexican States received a
            moderately satisfactory outcome with low or negligible risk
            to development outcome. Both the Bank and Borrowers
            performances were moderately satisfactory. Ultimately there
            were three restructurings that took place. The first
            restructuring dropped Component 3 because most activities
            were not critical to the achievement of the PDO and were
            supported outside the Project, revised Component 2 to
            include the impact evaluation previously under Component 3,
            the provision of technical assistance to states to improve
            their prioritization of marginalized and indigenous schools,
            and the carrying out of an monitoring and evaluation survey
            to collect data from community members on the School Based
            Management model in Quality Schools Program (PEC) schools,
            among others. The restructuring also adjusted the results
            framework to ensure full measurement of the achievement of
            the PDO. A reallocation of part of the loan proceeds to
            increase the number of beneficiary schools and an extension
            of the closing date by one year were also part of this
            restructuring. The second restructuring reallocated all
            funds from Category 3 (Consultant Services) to Category 1
            (Goods, Works and Consultant's Services supported under
            direct support to schools). This change was needed because
            Ministry of Public Education (SEP) decided to finance the
            impact evaluation of PEC with its own resources. The third
            restructuring reallocated US$93,331.55 from Category 2
            (Incremental Project Costs) to Category 1 (Goods, Works and
            Consultants' Services supported under the direct
            support to schools). The change was necessary, given
            SEP's decision to finance the remaining operating costs
            with its own resources. There were six lessons learned from
            this project and they are as follows: (1) Early adjustment
            of PDO and project results framework is desirable. (2) A
            rigorous impact evaluation of PEC is crucial to understand
            the effect of the program on learning outcomes. (3) Local
            Education Authorities play an important role in planning and
            implementing federal programs on the ground. It is important
            to find compelling ways to ensure that all states provide
            their PEC counterpart financing in a timely manner and
            comply with management information systems (MIS) that are
            compatible with the federal MIS. (4) In future operations,
            Project procurement and FM should be simplified in regards
            to the direct support to schools to avoid burdening schools
            with excessive administrative requirements and delays in the
            reporting of disbursements and proof of expenditures from
            the Government to the Bank. (5) Moving into country systems
            in countries with a solid fiduciary structure could help
            expedite technical assistance procurement processes and
            ensure that countries benefit from the technical assistance
            built into the project designs without necessarily
            compromising healthy procurement procedures. (6) The
            simplification and dissemination of school planning
            instruments help disadvantaged schools put together initial
            school improvement plans and therefore allow them to benefit
            more frequently from programs such as PEC.
